titleStmt.title: Forms V and VI IPFV sound verbs

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for derived form V and VI IPFV sound verbs (yitkassar, yikassar?) - pattern + example.

revisionDesc.change: updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

item.label: yitCaCCiC/yitCaCCaC and yitCāCiC/yitCāCaC conditioned by adjacent consonants

cit.quote: he is slow, he takes his time

wib:featureValueObservation.note: In the Lebanese dialects these are characterised by an initial closed syllable in the imperfect:titʕallam (she learns), yitṣālaḥaw (they reconcile)"(Pickett 2005:245)
In the Lebanese dialects these are characterised by an initial closed syllable in the imperfect:titʕallam (she learns), yitṣālaḥaw (they reconcile)"(Pickett 2005:245)
In the Lebanese dialects these are characterised by an initial closed syllable in the imperfect:titʕallam (she learns), yitṣālaḥaw (they reconcile)"(Pickett 2005:245)
In the Lebanese dialects these are characterised by an initial closed syllable in the imperfect:titʕallam (she learns), yitṣālaḥaw (they reconcile)"(Pickett 2005:245)
In the Lebanese dialects these are characterised by an initial closed syllable in the imperfect:titʕallam (she learns), yitṣālaḥaw (they reconcile)"(Pickett 2005:245)
According to the examples in this source, this pattern showing the elision of -t- infix only happens in form V, and not in form VI.
According to the examples in this source, this pattern showing the elision of -t- infix only happens in form V, and not in form VI.
Forms V and VI (t-prefix) also function to derive passives, and, in the case of Form VI, there is a sense of reciprocity.
Form VI is less frequent. (al-Hazmy 1975:106)
Form V imperfect pattern may be heard as y(i)tiC1aC2C2aC3 or ytaC1aC2C2aC3. Where the performative in the perfect is unstressed, its vowel a is often centralised.

cit.quote: they ride away one following the other
he has an argument with each other

wib:featureValueObservation.note: No examples for form VI available.

See Behnstedt 1999:44
In this variety, all short vowels have merged to ə.
The older generation has a in the second stem vowel of Form V, see Talmoudi 1980, p.102.

cit.quote: it cuts itself in small pieces

wib:featureValueObservation.note: medio-passive for the second stem

cit.quote: he has a dispute with someone
